RATILWAYS AND CANALS



By an act of the Legislature, approved on the 2d
of February, 1836, the Company was empowered to
construct a bridge across the Susquehanna (4,400
feet), and extend the road through Marrisburg to
the Pennsylvania Canal, about three miles beyond
the then eastern terminus, and also to connect with
other roads centring at Harrisburg. 7his was the
original Cumberland Valley Road. That portion
from Chambersburg to Hagerstown was originally
known as the Franklin Railroad.

This company was chartered in Pennsylvania, on
the 12th of March, 1832, and in Maryland in the
same year, and was authorized to construct.a road
in continuation of the Cumberland Valley Railroad
from Chambersburg to Hagerstown. The road was
built in 1838, and after changing owners several
times, finally came into the hands of the Cumber-
land Valley Road, by which it is now operated.

The DorcHESTER AND DELAWARE RAILROAD runs
from Cambridge, Md., to Seaford, Del., a distance
of thirty-three miles, 5% miles of which are in the
State of Delaware, and was built by the - Philadel-
phia, Wilmington, and Baltimore Railroad Com-
pany, and leased to the Dorchester and Delaware
Railroad Company.

The D. & D. RR. Co. owns two locomotives, and
hires the other rolling-stock from the P., W., & B.
RR. Co.

The first work on this road was commenced Oc-
tober 23, 1867, and on November 8, 1869, it was
opened for passengers and freight.

Seaford, the eastern terminus, is on the Delaware
Railroad Line, and Cambridge, the western termi-
nus, is on the south side of the Choptank River,
twenty miles from its entrance into the Chesapeake
Bay, and is the county-seat of Dorchester County.
Steamers to and from Baltimore connect with the
road at this point.

The EasteEry SHORE RAILROAD was chartered by
the Maryland Legislature in the year 1853, and the
company organized February 22d, 1859.

The road from Salisbury to Crisfield was built by
George A. Parker, of Boston, Mass., under one con-
tract, the work being commenced in August, 1865.
In March, 1866, the road was opened for business to
Princess Anne, and in October of the same year
‘was opened to its terminus at Crisfield.

The entire length of the road from Crisfield to
Delmar, a point on the dividing-line between the
States of Maryland and Delaware, is thirty-eight
miles; and at this point it becomes continuous with
the Delaware Railroad.

The Eastern Shore Railroad hasseveral important
connections, two of which are already completed,
and another projected. The Wicomico and Poco-
moke Railroad connects with it at Salisbury; the
‘Worcester Railroad being connected by means of
the Wicomico and Pocomoke. These roads traverse
a rich and prosperous section of country, making
them very important tributaries to the Eastern Shore
Railroad ; the length of the two roads being about
thirty-seven miles. '

The next important branch is the one leading
from near Princess Anne to Newtown, a distance
of nine miles. This road, just completed, may some
day be continued, extending through the Eastern
Shore counties in Virginia, of Accomac and North-
ampton.

The Eastern Shore Railroad, with proposed ex-
tensions, is, geographically, the most direct air-line
route between the North and the South. The dis-
tance from Crisfield to Norfolk, Va., by actual survey,
is eighty-four miles, connecting at Norfolk with the
Seaboard and Roanoke Railroad, and thence to
Charleston, S. C., and other points South. The dis-
tance between Charleston and New York can be
made, over this route, about six hours quicker than
by any other.

The projected connections are, (1.) The railroad to
extend from West Point, on the York River, Va,
to Pionkatank on the Chesapeake Bay, thence by



steam thirty-five miles to Crisfield; (2.) The Wash-
ington and Point Lookout Railroad, from Washing-
ton, D. C., to the mouth of the Potomac River at
Point Lookout, in St. Mary’s County, Md., which
road is now partly built, and is expected soon to be
finished ; thence by steamer to Crisfield, a distance
of thirty miles; and (3.) The Baltimore and Drum
Point Railroad, extending from that point to Balti-
more, and connecting by steamer from Drum Point
to Cristield, a distance of forty-five miles.

The grades of the Eastern Shore Railroad are re-
markably easy, and its direction nearly an air-line.
At Delmar, its northern terminus, it is thirty-two fect
above tide-water; at Salisbury, twenty-six; Princess
Anne, fourteen; Kingston, twelve; Crisfield, its
southern terminus, four —making twenty-eight feet
in thirty-eight miles. The road is in a prosperous
condition, and its business steadily increasing, and is
surely destined to become a most important connect-
ing-link between the Atlantic seaboard section of the
South and the great cities of the North.

The KrxT CouNTY RAILROAD Was commenced in
1869, and is now completed from Massey’s Cross
Roads to a point five miles beyond Chestertown,
near Belle Air, a distance of twenty-five miles.

There is a branch or lateral road, five-eighths of a
mile long, from the depot in the precincts of Ches-
tertown to Chester River. At the terminus on the
river a fine substantial wharf has been erected. The
direction through which the road passes is one of the
finest agricultural sections in the country. It is in
contemplation to extend the road from Belle Air to
some point on the Chesapeake Bay, from which a
steamer can run to Baltimore in 1§ hours.

In 1868, the Legislature of Maryland authorized
the Delaware RR. Co. to construect a road from Mas-
sey’s Cross Roads to the Delaware line, and the Del-
aware Legislature authorized the same company to
construct a road from some point on the Delaware
TRailroad to meet the proposed road from Massey’s.
In 1869 they constructed this road from Townsend, on
the Delaware Road to Massey’s Cross Roads in
Maryland. Thisis known as the Townsend Branch,
and is ten miles long.

There is a railroad from Massey’s Cross Roads
through Millington, in Kent, and through Queen
Anne County to Centreville, about twenty miles in
length, called the QuEEN ANNE AND KENT RATLROAD.
This road and the Kent County Railroad lease the
Townsend Branch,and thus have direct connections,
through the Declaware Railroad, with all the main
lines. :

About 9,000 passengers travelled over the Kent
County Railroad in 1871. The businessisimproving,
and, if the Bay connections are made, will increase
still more. A telegraph is being constructed along
the line.

The MARYLAND AND DELAWARE Ratnroap Co. was
chartered in Maryland in the year 1854, and in the
State of Delaware in 1857. This company was
authorized to construct a road from Clayton, on the
Delaware Railroad, to Oxford, on the Choptank, an
arm of the Chesapeake Bay, a distance of fifty-four
miles.

The work of construction was commenced on the
27th of December, 1857, and was completed, with
the exception of the pier, in 1871. The road has a
length of fourteen miles in Delaware and forty in
Maryland.

At its terminus on the Chesapeake Bay there is a
fine and commodious harbor, from which a daily line
of steamers runs to Baltimore; and one to Norfolk,
Va., is proposed.

The MEerroroLiTAN BraNcH RAILR0OAD was char-
tered in the District of Columbia by Congress on
the 3d of March, 1853, and by the Legislature of
Maryland on the 5th of April of the same year.
The line of the road extends from Washington City
to a junction with the Baltimore and Ohio Railroad
near Point of Rocks. Work was commenced in
1854, and completed in 1872.

“Wilmington, and Baltimore.



The NorTnerN CENTRAL RATLROAD, extending from
Baltimore, Md., to Sunbury, Pa., a distance of 138
miles, was formed by the consolidation of several
roads in Pennsylvania, and what was originally
known as the Baltimore and Susquehanna Railroad
in Maryland.

The Baltimore and Susquehanna Railroad Co. was
chartered on the 13th of March, 1828, with authority
to construct a road from Baltimore to the north line
of the State, thus connecting with any road that
might be constructed in Pennsylvania, with a view
of continuing the line northward. Work was be-
gun in the year following, and the road completed
as far as the Relay Ilouse, a distance of seven
miles from the city of Baltimore, on the 4th of July,
1831. And on the 16th of October it was extended
eleven miles further to Timonium.

In the same year, the branch to Owing’s Mills, a
distance of nine miles, was opened. The section
from Timonium to the State line, twenty-five miles,
was begun#¥in May, 1835, and completed in the early
part of 1838.

Shortly after the completion of this last section,
the York and Maryland Line Railroad built a con-
tinuation from the Maryland Line to York, Pa.

On the 10th of April, 1854, the Legislature of
Maryland passed an act authorizing the consoli-
dation of the Baltimore and Susquehanna and the
York and Maryland Line. This consolidation hav-
ing been approved by the stockholders of the several
companies, was consummated on the 4th of Decem-
ber following; and on the 1st of January, 1855, the
new company commenced its operations.

The PurrapeLrura AND BALTIMORE CENTRAL RAIL-
roAD. — The portion of this road in Maryland was
originally known as the Baltimore and Philadelphia
Railroad. The company was chartered in May,
1852, and organized in October, 1853. On the 25th
of June, 1854, it was consolidated into the Philadel-
phia and Baltimore Central Railroad, and in June,
1856, the work of construction was commenced in
Cecil County; but in the fall of the same year ope-
rations in Maryland were suspended.

In 1866, the road was completed to Rising Sun,
and was finished to the junction with the Columbia
and Port Deposit Railroad, on the Octoraro, near
Rowlandsville, four miles above Port Deposit, in the
spring of 1869.

The line now in use commences at the Maryland
line below Nottingham Station, and extends to C. &
P. D. Junction, a distance of 9} miles.

The PHILADELPHIA, WILMINGTON AND BALTIMORE
RarLroap. — This company is a consolidation of four
railroad companies. The Philadelphia and Dela-
ware Counties, chartered by the Legislature of Penn-
sylvania on the 2d of April, 1831; the Wilmington
and Susquchanna, chartered by the Legislature of
Delaware on the 18th of January, 1832; the Mary-
land and Delaware, chartered by the Legislature of
Maryland in 1831; and the Baltimore and Port De-
posit Company, chartered by the Legislature of Mary-
land in December, 1831. In March, 1836, the title
of the Philadelphia and Delaware Counties Railroad
Company was changed to that of the Philadelphia,
On the 18th of April,
1836, the Wilmington and Susquehanna, and Dela-
ware and Maryland Companies also consolidated,
under the title of the Wilmington and Susquehanna
Railroad Company; .and on the 5th of IFFebruary,
1838, the Philadelphia, Wilmington and Baltimore,
the Wilmington and Susquehanna, and the Baltimore
and Port Deposit Companies, were consolidated,
under the title of the Philadelphia, Wilmington and
Baltimore Railroad Company.

Previous to the consolidation, the several compa-
nies had commenced, and most of them had com-
pleted, the respective links. The Philadelphia and
Delaware Counties Company had completed its road
in 1837. The Baltimore and Port Deposit also
opened its road to Havre de Grace, instead of Port
Deposit. In the same year (July, 1837,) the Mary-
